text: This is called short-circuiting, and Python does it, so you're good.

code:
>>> def foo():
...     print "Yay!"
... 
>>> if True and foo() is None:
...     print "indeed"
... 
Yay!
indeed
>>> if False and foo() is None:
...     print "nope"
...

text: UPDATE 2: Putting the relevant PEP (308) in my answer so it doesn't get overlooked in the excellent comment from @Somebody still uses you MS-DOS.
The second item isn't evaluated - you could verify this with a simple program:

code:
def boo():
  print "hi"
  return True

a = False
b = True

if a and b == boo():
  print "hi2"

text: Running it produces no output, so you can see that boo() is never called.
If var is False, evaluation stops.
See the Short-Circuit Behavior section in PEP 308.
The evaluation getSomeValue won't be evaluated:

code:
var = False
if var and foo():
   print "here"
else:
   print "there"

def foo():
   print "In foo"
   return False

text: The Python documentation says that and and or are short-circuiting, so no, var2 == getSomeValue() won't be evaluated if var is false.
